resources.string: Android 8.0 added \'Background Execution Limits\' to help with battery drain caused by apps running in background. Which means that AN2Linux might be killed by the system. So if you run Android 8.0+ and have problems with AN2Linux missing notifications, then you could try to run AN2Linux as a foreground service.
To hide the notification dot of the service notification, open the notification settings of this app, click on the service channel name and set the importance to low.

Android 6.0 added \'Doze\' to limit apps running in background, it can for example block network access. Disabling \'Doze\' for AN2Linux may be necessary for it to work properly (unless using a foreground service, foreground services don\'t get dozed). It may be worth to try this before going full foreground service mode. Click here to do that.
Send notifications from these apps only
Add a server to send notifications to
%d pixels\nMost notification daemons will scale the image to a specific size, just so you know
Force notification title to be app name
Maximum chars to include from title
Maximum chars to include from message
Don\'t send if phone screen is on
Don\'t send notifications if phone screen is on
For example an incoming or active phone call

This is different for every app, you have to tinker with this setting
With gmail it's notifications of type:
"2 new messages"
Apparently text messages from Viber is flagged as this

You need to tinker with this as well
It's probably best not to block but this is what android reference says:
"notification is relevant to the current device only and it is not recommended that it bridge to other devices"
For example Google Now Reminders is flagged as this
AN2Linux requires access to your notifications. When the notification settings will open, enable AN2Linux then hit the back button.
AN2Linux requires location permission to obtain the WiFi SSID. When the permission settings will open, grant the location permission.

Since Android 10+ AN2Linux requires fine instead of coarse location permission to obtain the WiFi SSID. It need it \'all the time\' to be able to use SSID whitelist. When the permission settings will open, grant the location permission.
AN2Linux requires location permission \'all the time\' to access WiFi SSID when running in background. When the permission settings will open, grant the location permission.

There are three different kind of "servers": WiFi, Mobile and Bluetooth.

What that means is simply that AN2Linux will only try to send notifications to a server if you are connected to that type.

For example if you are connected to WiFi it will only try to send to all enabled WiFi servers and not to any mobile servers.

Bluetooth is kinda special, here "connected" means that bluetooth is turned on.

Enter one or more SSID comma-separated
Example: WiFi1, wifi2, ssid\,with\,comma
Case-sensitive, escape comma with '\'
Leave empty to allow any
This is just the name to be shown in the server list in this app
Bluetooth not supported on your device
Certificate was already in database, just so you know
AN2Linux not enabled in enabled applications

AN2Linux generated on first run a 4096 bit RSA key and certificate.

This is only used for authentication to the server (your computer) and not for encryption.

After you have successfully paired with a server you should be able to see your fingerprint in the authorized_certs file at the beginning of a line.

authorized_certs file is located in:
$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/an2linux/
which per default is:
$HOME/.config/an2linux/

No app enabled for notification sync
Tap here to enter the \'Enabled applications\' settings
Title/message extraction requires Android 4.4+. So if title is included, it will always be forced to app name.
Your device does not support disabling battery optimizations
